column4: I am assuming that /etc/pmount.allow has to have each user who you want to be able to mount cdrom from nautilus? Is pmount only used in nautilus?
no, /etc/pmount.allow contains additional devices normal users shold be allowed to mount
you do not want to change it unless you know very well what you are doing
my problem is that I can mount cdroms from the command line but get an error "Can't execute pmount" when I try to mount the same cdrom from nautilus
you are not in the 'plugdev' group then (the default user is)
this is also on my list of bugs: https://launchpad.net/distros/ubuntu/+source/pmount/+bug/33232
ok that is helpful...why would nothing be in the pmount.allow file?
man pmount :)  pmount already allows users to mount all removable devices
I addes myself to plugdev and still unable to mount and gives the same "Can't execute pmount"
were you able to solve that by just adding the users to plugdev group?
you have to log out and back in to make the group addition become effective
were you able to solve mounting by adding users to plugdev group?
yes, of course
(I'm pmount upstream and Debian/Ubuntu maintainer :) )
pittit: I added myself to plugdev and still unable to mount and umount from nautilus
even after logging out and in?
what does 'pmount /cdrom' say?
will try again
should all users be added to plugdev by default when adding users?
it worked after logging in and out the second time...should all users be added to plugdev by default of adduser?
no, adduser doesn't do that; the GUI tool does, though (that's what normal users are supposed to find first ;) )
lol well "normal" is a subjective term...thanks a lot for point out the issue though
